titlestmt.title: Edward Young, Night Thoughts Copy 1: electronic edition
titlestmt.sponsor: The Institute for Advanced Technology in the Humanities, the Library of Congress, and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with a software grant from Inso Corporation and hardware and software grants from Sun Microsystems
titlestmt.funder: The National Endowment for the Humanities, 2000-02
Paul Mellon Centre for Studies in British Art, 1997-98

filedesc.extent: XML file derived from 1 SGML (ISO 8879) encoded file approx. 240KB; 36 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 150KB to 2500KB
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of an electronic edition of two copies—one uncolored and one hand colored—of Blake's engraved illustrations to Edward Young's Night Thoughts (1797). Both copies are presented in our Preview mode, one that provides all the features of the Archive except Image Search and Inote (our image annotation program).
With what must have been enormous energy, Blake executed 537 water colors illustrating the poem's nine sections, which Young called "Nights," for the publisher Richard Edwards. The 1797 volume included a selection of illustrations for the first four Nights, but Edwards closed his publishing business before any further volumes could be issued. Many copies include a two-page "Explanation of the Engravings," possibly written by Blake's friend and fellow-artist Henry Fuseli. The texts of these commentaries are included in the Editor's Notes for each plate.
The colorist(s) of the twenty-seven traced colored copies have never been convincingly identified. The copy now published in the Archive, from the Huntington Library, was very probably colored shortly after publication.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible through the continuing support of the Library of Congress, the Institute for Advanced Technology in the Humanities at the University of Virginia, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and by the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

changestmt.respstmt: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill Project Manager and Technical Editor: William ShawConversion: Aziza Technology AssociatesWesley N. RaabeProject Assistants: Christopher N. Jackson, Sarah E. Jones, Kari Kraus, Ashley Reed, Wayne C. Ripley, Sarah Tolf

objdescid.note: Blake probably began work on the *Night Thoughts* water-color designs in late 1794 or early 1795. The engravings bear imprints dated 1796 and 1797 and were published in 1797.

objinfo.objsize: ranging between 33.9 x 28.4 cm. and 40.5 x 32.8 cm.The leaf size barely accommodates some of the plates, many of which were not precisely registered to the leaves during printing. As a result, most copies of the book contain at least a few plates in which the full image or the imprint was not printed.
objinfo.leafsize: 41.0 x 32.1 cm.The leaves in this copy have been trimmed. In an uncut copy, the leaves are approx. 42.5 x 33.5 cm.
objinfo.watermark: 1794 J WhatmanIn this copy, the watermark appears on pages vii/viii, 9/10 (Object 6), 11/12 (Object 7), 19/20 (Object 12), 29/30, 37/38 (Object 21), 47/48, 55/56 (Object 28), 85/86 (Object 37), 91/92 (Object 41), and 95 (Object 43).
objinfo.framelines: The text panels on the fly-titles to Nights 1-2 (Objects 1 and 11) are framed with multiple lines. Two lines frame the text panel on the fly-title to Night 3 (Object 24); there is no text panel on the fly-title to Night 4 (Object 31). All other text panels are framed with a single line.
objinfo.stabholes: There are a few fragments of stab holes in some leaves, but these were created when the volume was bound in the twentieth century.

provenance.name: Robert N. Essick
provenance.note: The copy was acquired at a Christie's New York auction, 20 May 1983, lot 5, with the first published state of Plate 11 bound in (Justin Schiller for Essick, $2750). Earlier history not known. The first published state of Plate 11 has been removed and housed separately.

desc.objtitle: NIGHT the FIRST,ON LIFE, DEATH AND IMMORTALITY., Object 1 (Bentley 515.1)

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "Death, in the character of an old man, having swept away with one hand part of the family seen in this print, is presenting with the other their spirits to immortality."

lg.l: NIGHT the FIRST,Lines 1-6 were printed from the plate rather than as part of a separate letterpress printing. This engraved text was probably executed by Blake, but it is also possible that it was cut by a writing engraver.
Pubd. June 27th. 1796, by R. Edwards, No. 142 New Bond Street.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "Sleep forsaking the couch of care, sheds his influence, by the touch of his magic wand, on the shepherd's flock."

lg.l: Pubd. June 27th. 1796, by R. Edwards, No. 142 New Bond Street.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "The imagery of dreaming variously delineated according to the poet's description in the passage referred to by the *."

lg.l: Pubd. June. 27th. 1796, by R. Edwards, No. 142 New Bond Street.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "Death, tolling a bell, summonses a person from sleep to his kingdom the grave."

lg.l: Pubd. June, 27, 1796, by R. Edwards, No. 142 New Bond StreetAll but fragments of the imprint letters have been trimmed off in this copy.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "The universal empire of Death characterized by his plucking the sun from his sphere."

lg.l: inv & scThe left side of the monogram signature has been slightly trimmed in this copy.
Pubd. June, 27, 1796, by R. Edwards, 142 New Bond Street.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "An evil genius holding two phials, from one pours disease into the ear of a shepherd, and from the other scatters a blight among his flock; intimating that no condition is exempt from affliction."

lg.l: Pubd. June 27th. 1796, by R. Edwards, No. 142 New Bond Street.The imprint has been trimmed off in this copy.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "The frailty of the blessings of this life demonstrated, by a representation in which the happiness of a little family is suddenly destroyed by the accident of the husband's death from the bite of a serpent."

lg.l: Pubd. June 27th. 1796, by R. Edwards, No. 142 New Bond Street.The imprint has been trimmed off in this copy.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "The insecurity of life exemplified by the figure of Death menacing with his dart, and doubtful which he shall strike; the mother, or the infant at her breast."

lg.l: Pubd. June 27th. 1796, by R. Edwards, No. 142 New Bond Street.All but fragments of the imprint have been trimmed off in this copy.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "The author encircled by thorns, emblematical of grief, lamenting the loss of his friend to the midnight hours."

lg.l: Pubd. June 27. 1796, by R. Edwards, No. 142, New Bond Street.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "The struggling of the soul for immortality, represented by a figure holding a lyre and springing into the air, but confined by a chain to the earth."

lg.l: London, Pubd. June, 27, 1796, by R. Edwards, 142 New Bond Street.

desc.objtitle: NIGHT the SECONDON TIME, DEATH AND FRIENDSHIP., Object 11 (Bentley 515.11)

objnote.p: The plate in this copy is in the second of two published states. The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "Time endeavouring to avert the arrow of Death from two friends."

lg.l: NIGHT the SECONDLines 1-6 were printed from the plate rather than as part of a separate letterpress printing. This engraved text was probably executed by Blake, but it is also possible that it was cut by a writing engraver.
Pubd. June 27th. 1796, by R. Edwards, No. 142 New Bond Street.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "A skeleton discovering the first symptoms of re-animation on the sounding of the archangel's trump."

lg.l: Pubd. June, 27, 1796, by R. Edwards, No. 142 New Bond Street.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "A man measuring an infant with his span, in allusion to the shortness of life."

lg.l: Pubd. June 27th. 1796 by R. Edwards No. 142 New Bond Street. The final two letters of "Street" and the terminal punctuation are poorly printed in this copy.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "Our inattention to the progress of Time illustrated by a figure of that god, (as he is called by the poet) creeping towards us with stealthy pace, and carefully concealing his wings from our view."

lg.l: Pubd. June 27th. 1796 by R. Edwards No. 142 New Bond Street.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "Time having passed us, is seen displaying his ‘broad pinions,’ and treading nearly on the summit of the globe, eager ‘to join anew Eternity his sire.’"

lg.l: Pubd. June 27. 1796, by R. Edwards, No. 142 New Bond Street.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "The same power [time] in his character of destroyer, mowing down indiscriminately the frail inhabitants of this world."

lg.l: inv & scThe right side of the monogram is slightly trimmed in this copy.

Pubd. June 27. 1796, by R. Edwards, No. 142 New Bond Street. The imprint is known only from a proof impression in the manuscript of *The Four Zoas*, page 135. It was probably retained in the published state of the plate, but we have not found it in any published copy of the book, probably because the imprint was either trimmed off or engraved too low on the plate to print.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "Conscience represented as a recording angel; who is veiled, and in the act of noting down the sin of intemperance in a bacchanalian."

lg.l: Pubd. June 27. 1796, by R. Edwards, No. 142, New Bond Street.
lg.note: The imprint has been trimmed off in this copy.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "A good man conversing with his past hours, and examining their report. The hours are drawn as aerial and shadowy beings, some of whom are bringing their scrolls to the inquirer, while others are carrying their record to heaven."

lg.l: Pubd. June, 27th. 1796, by R. Edwards, No. 142 New Bond Street.The imprint has been trimmed off in this copy.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "Belshazzar terrified in the midst of his impious debauch by the hand-writing on the wall. The passage marked out by the asterisk, sufficiently explains the propriety with which the story is alluded to by the poet, and delineated by the artist."

lg.l: Pubd. June 27th. 1796, by R. Edwards, No. 142 New Bond Street.The plate in this copy has been trimmed very close to the imprint. Some of the letters of the imprint did not print clearly.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "A parent communicating instruction to his family."

lg.l: Pubd. June, 27th. 1796, by R. Edwards. No. 142, New Bond Street.The imprint has been trimmed off in this copy.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "The story of the good Samaritan, introduced by the artist as an illustration of the poet's sentiment, that love alone and kind offices can purchase love."
The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "Angels attending the death-bed of the righteous, and administering consolation in his last moments."

lg.l: London, Pubd. Jan: 4, 1797, by R. Edwards. 142 New Bond Street.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "Angels conveying the spirit of the good man to heaven."

lg.l: London: Pub. Mar. 22, 1797, by R. Edwards, 142 New Bond Street.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "A female figure, who appears from the crescent beneath her feet to have surmounted the trials of this world, is admitted to an eternity of glory: eternity is represented by its usual emblem—a serpent with its extremities united."

lg.l: NIGHTLines 1-4 were printed from the plate rather than as part of a separate letterpress printing. This engraved text was probably executed by Blake, but it is also possible that it was cut by a writing engraver.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "The folly and danger of pursuing the pleasures of sense as the chief objects of life illustrated by the figure of Death just ready to throw his pall over a young and wanton female."

lg.l: London, Pubd: Jan: 1, 1797. by R. Edwards, 142 New Bond Stt.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "The author supporting a female figure, and presenting her to the sun; whose aid he seems to solicit, and whose chariot is seen above, surrounded and in some measure obscured by clouds. The artist refers to the circumstance alluded to in the poem, of the author's having attended his step-daughter (Narcissa) who was languishing in a decline, to a more southern climate."

lg.l: London, Pubd. June 27. 1796, by R Edwards, 142 New Bond Strt.

objnote.p: An asterisk, indicating the line or passage illustrated, appears to the left of the last line on the previous text page, page 53. This line reads as follows: "The vale of death! that hush'd cimmerian vale,". The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "The vale of death, where the Power of darkness broods over his victims, as they are borne down to the grave by the torrent of a sinful life."

lg.l: Pub. Mar. 22. 1797, by R. Edwards, 142, New Bond Street.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "His guardian angel sent to reprove a mourner for his improper indulgence of sorrow on the tomb of his friend: with one hand the angel touches the object of his errand, and with the other points to those realms of light in which the deceased was at rest from his labours."

The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "Death with his uplifted dart just disclosing himself to a party of bacchanals; one of whom still continues his intoxicating draught, while his comrades discover symptoms of extreme alarm on the unexpected intrusion of so unwelcome a guest."
The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "To the eye of the righteous the countenance of the King of Terrors is changed into that of the Prince of Peace."
The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "The resurrection of our Saviour, typical of the resurrection of all his servants from the grave."

lg.l: THELines 1-3 were printed from the plate rather than as part of a separate letterpress printing. This engraved text was probably executed by Blake, but it is also possible that it was cut by a writing engraver.
Pubd. June 1st. 1797 by R. Edwards New Bond Street

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "Death, as a huntsman, pursuing with ferocious pleasure his human game."

lg.l: London, Pubd. June 27. 1796. by R Edwards, 142 New Bond Street.All but the tops of the letters of the imprint have been trimmed off in this copy.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "Two figures, intended to represent Sense and Reason, pointing to another scene of things, and admonishing the author that it is time for him to depart from the present."

lg.l: Pubd. June 1st. 1797, by R. Edwards, No. 142 New Bond Street.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "The Saviour represented in the furnace of affliction, and agonized with torture for the sins of the human race."

The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "The sun as described by the poet, averting his face (which he hides also with his hands) from the shocking spectacle of our Lord's sufferings."
The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "A personification of Thunder directing the adoration of the poet to the Almighty in heaven."

lg.l: Pubd. June 1st. 1797, by R. Edwards, No. 142 New Bond Street.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "The exalted views of a good man beyond the pleasures of this life, allegorically described by a figure in the clouds, with one hand fixed in the sky, and with the other pointing to the earth beneath him."
The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "Christ represented as the great philanthropist, receiving and instructing all ages and sexes."

lg.l: in & sThe monogram signature in the lower left corner of the plate has been trimmed off in this copy.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "Earnest prayer and intercourse with Heaven compared to the wrestling of Jacob with the angel for a blessing."

lg.l: Pubd. June 1st. 1797, by R. Edwards, No. 142 New Bond Street

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "The Saviour healing Affliction by a touch with his hand."
The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "The harmony between Faith and Reason, illustrated by Faith writing down the dictates of Reason."
The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "Angels retiring in grief and wonder from their charge of a determined infidel."

lg.l: Pubd. June 1st. 1797, by R. Edwards, No. 142 New Bond Street

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "A personification of Truth, as she is represented by the poet, bursting on the last moments of the sinner ‘in thunder and in flame.’"
